thread.title: PERRIS: Southern California Fair kicks off with a band
thread.title_full: PERRIS: Southern California Fair kicks off with a band - Press Enterprise

author: TOM SHERIDAN
title: PERRIS: Southern California Fair kicks off with a band
text:
BY TOM SHERIDAN 3, 2015 Updated: Oct. 4, 2015 10:24 a.m. 2015 SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA FAIR DATES: Runs daily through Oct. 11
HOURS: Saturday-Sunday, 11 a.m.-11 p.m.; Monday-Thursday, 4-11 p.m.; Friday noon-11 p.m.
DAILY TICKETS: General admission ages 12 and up, $8; ages 5-11, $4; ages 4 and under get in free
PARKING: $8
THEME: "Root-n, tootin fun"
Strike up the band, it’s time again for the Southern California Fair.
With the San Jacinto High School marching band leading the way blasting “Eye of the Tiger,” the Southern California Fair got underway Saturday morning, Oct. 3, with the traditional opening parade at the Lake Perris Fairgrounds.
It signaled the start of nine days of Ferris wheel rides, corndog snacks, music, motor sports, livestock and wandering entertainers such as the Be Bop Fairy, who also took part in the parade trailing soap bubbles that stretched 30 feet long and 10 feet wide.
“Everybody is looking their best,” said Carolina Raintree, aka the Be Bop Fairy.
Raintree, 30, a veteran fair performer, was resplendent with her blue and white butterfly face paint, mesh tube fairy dreads, pink hair ribbons and a silver gemstone affixed just above the bridge of her nose.
“It looks pretty good,” said Raintree, poised on roller skates standing in the middle of the midway. “A lot of people are out. The kids are happy. And the weather is nice.”
Indeed, with late-morning temperatures in the high 70s, conditions were much more comfortable than a year ago when the highs on opening day of the fair soared into the low triple-digits.
Katelyn Bloor, 12, of Moreno Valley identified her favorite activity early on — the Wow bubbles.
“It was just, like, an adrenaline rush,” Katelyn said.
You’ve seen the bubbles. They’re made of thermoplastic polyurethane and float in a shallow pool of water. The idea is to stand up and walk, generating a hamster-cage effect. That’s the idea, anyway.
“It’s really hard to stand,” Katelyn explained. “I mean, I fell a lot of times. It’s not easy.”
So what’s next?
“The monster trucks,” she said emphatically.
She wasn’t alone. A couple thousand people packed the main grandstand for the first of two monster truck shows at Budweiser Arena.
As the drivers posed in front of their gargantuan rigs, Gabriel Baleanu, 30, of Moreno Valley knelt a few yards from the fence that separates the fans from the track, trying to frame his 2-year-old son, Michael, and 4-year-old son, Gabriel, for a photo in front of Dawn Creten and her monster truck, the Scarlet Bandit.
“They love big trucks,” Baleanu said.
Next up for him and the boys would be the livestock exhibit at the north end of the fairgrounds. The fair is an annual outing for Baleanu and the boys.
“Every year it’s a beautiful thing,” he said. “The Orange County and L.A. fairs are a little bit too much for me. But the (Lake) Perris Fairgrounds is great.”
Contact the writer: 951-368-9682 or tsheridan@pe.com
